reviews.text: Most interesting part of town, with Barceloneta beach and port, Gothic part, La Rambla and many other interesting areas of town
Th Gothic quarter was very impressive and gave a good impression of the former life in Barcelona. Little shops, bars and restaurant are all friendly and not pushy. We enjoyed very much
This area is the best in Barcelona, with charming architecture and narrow streets with something of interest round every corner.
Liked this area best, with quality shops, restaurants and boutiques, charming architecture and narrow streets with something of interest round every corner.
We walked this area almost everyday and there's always a shop or place that we only just noticed while walking past. Includes Basilica de Santa Maria del Pi  and the Cathedral of Barcelona

Its a nice area that you can feel the spanish vibe with all the palms and architecture with yellowish colors. There is not much benches to sit but you can chill around the fountain a bit to eat something and rest a bit.
A little messy and dirty, full of tourists and some beggars, but also full of history and historic buildings so worth your time and tour.

The area of Barcelona covered by Cuitat Vella includes the great majority of the best bits (IMO). It includes the Gòtic and El Born areas, Barceloneta and Port Vell. I have spent many happy hours and days in these parts of Barcelona. 

Whilst other areas have highlights this area draws my attention continually.

You'll find narrow streets and squares here, with Gothic mansions, museums, historic churches, bars and restaurants. The Placa del Rei is reputedly the place where King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella welcomed Columbus after his voyage to Americ. Plenty of good restaurants

One of my favorite, even adored, places in Barcelona. I fell in love at once, in the confidential" home " atmosphere of this place, I like to watch here performances of jazz collectives and flamenco dances.

If you are out for a stroll during the evening hours this is a great place to sit down and people watch.  The square is well policed so it is a very safe place and you won't be harassed by the street folks.  The square is surrounded by a number of very good restaurants with outside eating areas that we were able to test out during our summer stay.  The square is ideally situated just off the Ramba where the nightly action of tourists and locals never disappoint.
wandered through a lane and found ourselves here!  A beautiful square surrounded by restaurants and wine bars.  I love hideaway for a peaceful drink and people watching
Charming place to walk around or just sit and people watch from a cafe. Nice restaurants and shops .

Great place to visit with lots of small squares to explore, especially during the day. Even though we were 4 grown ups we realised we were being targeted at only around 10pm so we dashed into a a restaurant and the staff told us we needed to be careful and stick to the busy well lit streets.

Not only for architects and engineers is the most famous area around Las Ramplas interesting. It is a special experience as a tourist, hobby photographer or amazed to experience the unbelievable achievements in the construction and architecture of a present past era. Take your time for a special experience.
Our hotel was on La Rambla in the Ciutat Vella and we could not get tired of walking in the small streets since it was so beautiful.

If you enjoy medieval and older cities, go here!  This sector of winding streets is redolent with history. This sector offers an old Jewish sector, a Roman wall, the Catedral de Barcelona and much, much more. Hungry?  Thirsty?  Restaurants, bars, gelato shops and more abound as well.
Such a cool place to walk around for a few hours. Las Ramblas, The Boqueria market and much, much more to see there. Tons of restaurants, great shopping, and amazing Architecture!
The old city of Barcelona sheds light on the city's past from an artistic, architectural and cultral perspective.  I suggest visiting Ciutat Vella.
Been visiting this most interesting city for over 40 years, and this area is the old Barcelona.  I never tire of visiting it.

Enjoyed wandering through the historic streets of the old city, with the many shops and cafes lining the routes. Particularly loved the haberdashery shops with their focus on buttons and fastenings - fascinating! Little historic courtyards in the area, especially those close to the cathedral. Pedestrianised, by and large, which makes for easy walking. Excellent churros at Xurreria at Carrer dels Banks Nous 8.
If we return to Barcelona ( WHEN we return to Barcelona!) think we would take a guided tour of this area as there seemed such a lot to see.

Leave behind the busy Rambla and, well enjoy the slightly less busy old town.  But there is so much to discover and you can always find a quiet spot.

Be on your guard - pickpockets follow the crowds and they are good at what they do!
I enjoyed a lot walking around this neighbourhood. Buildings made of stone and narrow streets take you to another time.

Ciutat Vella is Barcelona in the "old days"; it is the Catalan word for  Old City. It is probably one of the most beautiful parts of Barcelona. It is certainly old, with its old, even ancient narrow streets which seem to be enclosed by huge, very tall buildings. There are plenty of shops around, of all types. And the most well known of them , La Rambla, is in the middle of this old city. If you wish you can go for a walk by the water, which is the harbour, and that's part of this area too. Barri Gòtic, the oldest part of the city, is perhaps the loveliest. There are numerous sights in this district that you can visit. And there are a lot of things to like in Ciutat Vella, but there might be some not so good as well, but we did not notice any during our short visit there. It's definitely worth checking out.

this area should be added to your list of walking around Barca

lots to see and appreciate and remind you of old Barca

We took a detour off the Rambla and the crowds melted away. Wandering at random through the narrow streets and small squares amongst the fine old buildings was much more fun than the nearby crowds. Well worth a look.
Amazing if you like to explore beautiful old and narrow streets. Atmosphere is great, very touristic but it’s one of the best area in Barcelona. A lot of surprises, you will see many things!
It is one of Barcelona's many magical places a real experience to walk along the narrow streets...feel that atmposphere.

This old gothic town is a perfect place to walk and explore.  The buildings and the history is something to take in and enjoy.  Shops, and outside performers make it a pleasant afternoon to turn a corner and find yet another small road to see and experience.

If you have time and do not have specific attractions that you have to see when entering this area, just wandering around without consistently looking at your map since you can find very beautiful houses, buildings, stores, or anything that may catch your attention.

It’s very easy to get lost in these old but beautiful and tricky streets. We loved the atmosphere, it felt authentic. A lot of history and the architecture is always beautiful in Barcelona. Just a perfect walk!
This is the old part of the city. Wander around, get a bit lost, have a drink and a few tapas and enjoy the atmosphere!

Pleasant staff, definitely only 3 star ⭐️Hotel - being so close to the University made it very noisy at night, students partying into the early morning. If you stay here it’s great for accessing the old town and The Ramblas- just turn left as you leave hotel not right!
Cultural, historical and architectural experience in a colorful neighborhood. Easy to get around thanks to good signage.

Walking through the narrow streets of the Ciutat Vella (old city) , with its cafes, restaurants, shops , plazzas and churches is like having all of Barcelona essence captured in one quarter. If you have only couple of hours in the city -would recommend to go there and feel its Gothic architecture, Catalan culture and way of life. Interesting, fascinating and absorbing.
There was a festival going on so it was a very busy place, great to see the different traditions and enjoy the festive air

wander around and you'll find something that leads you to another
Just remember were your hotel is
encompasses  quite a few stores
This is what Barcelona means to me.   Deli's, Markets, Cheese, Wine, people, Tapas, Sangria, Oysters!!!!
You may stop for a museum or site, but even  just wondering around the alleys and squares is a great experience.
There is so much to see and do in this area of the city as this is its oldest part.  Not to be missed.  The longer you wander around the more you discover.

Ciutat Vella translated is old city.  This is the old part of Barcelona.  The Roman walls that surrounded the old city can still be seen.  Next to the Barcelona Cathedral, you can see the old Roman Wall, related towers and aqueduct that supplied the Old City with water.  Also in Ciutat Vella are many museums, churches, squares, the City Hall and Generalitat building.

Oh, to have had more time to explore Ciutat Vella! During our walk in this area, we had to repeatedly pinch ourselves.  Are we really in this amazing place where we can go back in time and feel we are in medieval Barcelona?  Allocate enough time in this place with a map and also a willingness to get lost.  Wonderful!
Beautiful medieval streets, Picasso museum, MEAM museum with its delightful jazz concerts, quirky little shops and bars, guitar music wafting through the air.

My travel agent chose this hotel as it was advertised as wheelchair accessible. It isn't. The breakfast was also very disappointing. On a positive it is close to La Rambla and a metro station. The Jacuzzi on the roof is good if you are able -bodied.
Streets around the old palace and besides the cathedral, this place must be visited accompanied by a local guide.

We stayed in the El Born neighbourhood fourteen years ago on our first trip but we definitely had walked around this area because I was able to revisit several places during our stay this time. Lots of great stuff here...bars, restaurants, shopping... you name it but I wouldn't recommend it for light sleepers! It does get noisy through the night!
As in all cities, there is an old neighborhood, and Barcelona is very beautiful. It is worth walking through its streets enjoying the views of the old buildings, and the architecture.

This is the old town or 'Gothic Quarter' of Barcelona. It is a wonderful maze of tiny streets where you'll find little shops, tapas bars and restaurants. Every now and again the lanes will open out onto a little square, and you'll also find the Gothic cathedral in this area which is worth a visit too. Very good.
Have a great time getting lost in the old town, it's great fun just wandering around. Pay attention to your stuff, there are pickpockets, but enjoy!
It's worth spending a day in the old town with its myriad individual shops and many bars and tapas places.
It's a good place to wander, you can take some amazing shots, or just enjoy the architecture, the shops and hidden treasures.

Usually refered  to as Gotico, the twisting stone paved narrow streets and small bright placas that are old Barcelona. Wander about and have a tourist map with you. Some shopping and sit about cafes, but many old tall buildings of charm and character. Mainly pedestrianised but be careful for fast moving bikes.
For those who are into cozy narrow streets with a historic feel, this is the place to go. Take your time to get a close look at the details!

The (sometimes extremely) narrow streets of this neighbourhood are a wonderful place to spend a couple of hours looking at a great variety of buildings. It's called the "Ciudad Gótica" (Goth City) by the locals and it really lives up to it's name. As with all of non-downtown Barcelona, small town opening times apply (you probably won't find any shop open between 1 and 5 PM).
Other than that if you're in the area, ENJOY!!!

This is one of those things you will simply enjoy on a stroll around Barcelona without never knowing it has a rich history--any number of the tours will point this out to you and explain the fascinating events that occurred here and will point out evidence of its past.
A great walk and an example of how the city life used to be, relaxing walk and a must do when visiting Barcelona.
No words can express all the architecture and beauty we saw on our visit. Barcelona has all this unique and special places. Mixed styles, eras, and culture. Well worth the trip

This is the medieval part of Barcelona, La Ramblas is part of the Gothic district, with narrow streets, with charming little corners, nice squares to stroll, true gems and the old Jewish quarter; art shops, vintage shops and quality foodie shops; buildings with ornate balconys with potted plants; the ciutat Vella, a very nice district to visit, also the market and the cathédral;
it seems it's an expansive pedestrian old historic center.
This is the "Old City", perhaps the most historic area of Barcelona with narrow lanes and alleys and many of the oldest churches and buildings. Definitely a place to explore when in Barcelona.

"Old City" Barcelona is comprised of four districts: Barri Gotic; Raval; Sant Pere, Santa Caterina i la Ribera (El Borne); and Barceloneta. While Ciutat Vella is quite expansive, Barri Gotic is the oldest of the districts, dating back to the Romans from 133 B.C.  The Barcelona Cathedral is in the heart of the Barri Gotic, which is primarily pedestrian designated, with numerous narrow, winding alleyways. The Ciutat Vella is our favorite part of Barcelona, reflecting thousands of years of Barcelona's rich history.

Beautiful historic buildings separated by narrow roads with small boutiques and restaurants. Beautiful balconies with plants and laundry hanging down over the couble stone streets. Very picturesque, loved the exposed brick walls and oversized original doors!
Like the wonderful alleys in Venice, this is simply a breathtaking walk where you can immerse yourself in History

Narrow streets, hidden gems... you just need to walk (or, better, get lost) and enjoy this beautiful part of Barcelona. Some parts may be a bit lonely at dark, and although it is not dangerous you may feel uncomfortable (it is better to visit during the day).

We stayed for 3 nights last weekend with another couple. Our rooms were immaculate- clean & tidy, and the staff were so helpful & friendly. Special thanks to Sandra on reception who suggested an excellent place to eat on our first night. Our sheets were changed at least once while we were there which we didn't expect. The hair dryer was as good as you'd get at home, @ the shower was both powerful @ hot. Location wise, it's 5 minutes walk from Place des Catalunya where the metro stops, and 3-4 minutes walk to La Rambla. Would stay here again in a heartbeat. Even has a jacuzzi on the roof terrace 😀
This is a beautifully historic area of Barcelona. I loved getting lost in the narrow streets and looking up at all the balconies... Another world

While on a photography tour of Barcelona in August 2016, I spent several hours exploring this area of the city.  Like the Gothic Quarter, it feels more local than touristy and not as crowded.  There are many churches, small courtyards, and quiet streets and alleys to experience.  Highly recommended!

We visited the city in April and found this hotel to be well placed for just about everything, walking, metro station restaurants. All good. Its one drawback is that it can be a bit noisy if you are at the front of the hotel. This is because it is about 1/4 mile away from the university and the plethora of students. Having said that it was comfortable, the rooms were up to standard, breakfast was filling, so YES we would go back there
We had a walking tour guide provided by our tour and she was brilliant.  Toured the Barrio Gotica and old Jewish quarter. Amazing!
Found our way there from the harbour ,wandered about for an hour or two ,and enjoyed the Atmosphere the narrow alleys gave
The gothic quarter is a combination of small narrow street together with a number of monuments and squares. Spend some time to just walk around and discover new details around each corner.
While there are lots of tourist-type shops and eating places, also so many stores/bar-restos of beautiful quality, tucked away on narrow side streets. Lots of fun!

The very best places to start your visit to Barcelona!  Stroll around and "get lost" in the warren of tight streets and alleys of the old town.  Great shops, boutiques, galleries, restos!  Surprisingly safe both day and night.

Very interesting location just set behind Las Ramblas. It looked scruffy during the day but really came alive at night. Loved the little "Pop Up" Bars that opened after about 9ppm and served some of the best Tapas. Our hotel was fairly basic but very clean, lovely staff and close to everything while still being in a quiet area.

Ciutat Vella is the old city, the centre of Barcelona, made up of four neighbourhoods with La Rambla running through the centre.  Our hotel was in the Barri Gotic neighbourhood of the old city and it was a great vantage point from which to visit the Ciutat Vella.  There is plenty to see in the area like the Basilica, the Boqueria Market, the Picasso Museum.  The area is full of narrow streets, back streets, and alley ways, but also boasts beautiful plazas like Placa Reial.  There are lots of good restaurants, cafes, and bars to choose from as well as boutiques for shopping.

Having discovered this neighbourhood during our last stay in Barcelona, we were determined to spend a bit more time there during our most recent visit to the city. It is located not far off La Rabla and adjacent to Barcelona Cathedral. 
During our most recent visit to the area, we spent most of our time one morning, wandering through the narrow laneways and alleys, just absorbing the ambience created by the unique architecture of the buildings and the numerous fascinating shops, cafe and bars located there.
This small neighbourhood really is the true essence of old Barcelona. Its charm make it a "must visit" area for any tourists spending time in Barcelona.

Me and my friend visited Barcelona and choose to stay in this hotel because of the location factor, the rooms are good front desk staff is nice and cooperative. We booked through booking.com at much higher rate than the rack rate at the hotel.Everything else was perfect.

Recommendation: Compare rates before booking it through booking.com

Get your best shoes, you'll need them to discover all the streets and corners of this area! La Barceloneta, El Gòtic, El Raval, La Rambla, Sant Pere, Santa Caterina i la Ribera, etc. Many things to see!

Good area to walk around, coupled with the Gothic Quarter. Old, tight streets with small local shops, bars etc. Not every street is 'chocolate box' pretty, but bags of character. Well worth a visit, just to amble along. Easily accessed from La Rambla.

The location is excellent, a 3 minute walk from Ramblah Street. A relatively small hotel, very clean and cozy rooms.  looked renovated, modernly decorated. The service of reception and maids is excellent. Ready to help. We really enjoyed staining there. In the category of three star hotel I really recommend.
Not fancy but great location and accommodations for our family while in Barcelona. Staff was very helpful. Note you can also use pool at sister hotel - which is very nice.
